results.title: Mr. Deeds goes to town
results.brief_description: One of the most successful comedies, this is the story of Longfellow Deeds (Gary Cooper), an unassuming, tuba-playing young country hick who inherits his uncle’s $20 million estate. He is catapulted from small-town peace to New York turmoil. Discovering he’s been duped by crooked big city associates and the beautiful girl reporter (Jean Arthur) whom he loves, Deeds decides to give away his fortune to the needy. His lawyer interprets this as a sign of insanity and a bitter courtroom battle ensues with Deeds refusing to testify. Only love can save the day. This timeless “little-man-against-the-world” comedy-drama won Capra the 1936 Academy Award for Best Director and received five Oscar nominations, including Best Picture and Best Actor.

results.title: The Exorcist
results.creator_credit: William Friedkin, William Peter Blatty and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The Exorcist occupies a central position in the history of horror films, an almost sadistically malevolent experience in terror. Regan (Linda Blair) is a young girl entering puberty and she becomes possessed by the spirit of an ancient demon. Her mother (Ellen Burstyn) finds that there is no assistance in the scientific pragmatism of the modern world and she hesitantly turns to the occult rites of Catholicism and Orthodoxy in order to rid her daughter of the monster. The exorcism scenes attain a disturbing authenticity and they are based on the official Catholic Church rites of exorcism. “The Exorcist” is a film that feeds on our most intimate fears and terrors and not a film for the easily frightened. Stars Max Van Sydow as Father Merrin. Based on the book by William Peter Blatty. Mercedes McCambridge is the voice of the Devil. Part of Tubular Bell by Mike Oldfield used on the soundtrack.

results.title: Mountains of the moon
results.creator_credit: Bob Rafelson, Daniel Melnick and Indieprod
results.brief_description: In the 1850’s, two British officers, Captain Richard Burton and Lieutenant John Hanning Speke, set out on a spectacular adventure to discover the source of the Nile. As they pushed deeper and deeper into the hitherto unexplored regions of the African wilderness, they forged strong bonds of friendship in order to survive the great dangers which befell them. It was ironical then, that a friendship which had endured so much in Africa, was ultimately destroyed by the rigidity and competitiveness of Victorian England and its aristocracy. Burton, played by Patrick Bergin, is a larger than life character; a “maverick” geographer whose love affair and marriage to Isabelle, (Fiona Shaw), was “the stuff from which legends were made”. Speke, (Iain Glen), was the son of an aristocrat, bound by the strict conventions of his time. Together they embarked on one of the greatest explorations in history. Divided, their friendship in tatters, and their reputations in jeopardy, Speke ended his life tragically, and Burton quit England.

results.title: The Little Colonel
results.creator_credit: David Butler, B G De Sylva Productions and Fox Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
After a blistery Southern Colonel (Lionel Barrymore) banishes his daughter (Evelyn Venable) for marrying a Northener (John Lodge), he refuses to see her even when she returns years later with her young daughter (Shirley Temple). As outspoken as her grandfather, the ingenious child turns on plenty of charm and wins his heart. Includes a remarkable tap dance/soft-shoe routine with the famous Bill “Mr Bojangles” Robinson. In a role she makes her own, Hattie McDaniel of “Gone with the wind” fame, plays Mammy. The original production was in black and white, with the final scene shot in technicolor, however this version has been computer colourised.

results.title: The Court-martial of Billy Mitchell
results.creator_credit: Otto Preminger, Milton Sperling and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: After World War One, Brigadier General Billy Mitchell, (Gary Cooper), forsees the deadly power and military importance of airplanes, previously used only by the US Army for reconnaissance. His superiors refuse to heed his advice, despite convincing evidence. When Mitchell persists in his campaign, he is called before a Court Martial and branded a traitor. Although General Duthrie, (Charles Bickford) attempts a cover-up at the trial, it becomes a media event, revealing how one man’s vision can shape history. This was the first screen appearance of Elizabeth Montgomery.

results.title: Cool hand Luke
results.creator_credit: Stuart Rosenberg, Gordon Carroll, Warner Bros Pictures and Jalem Productions
results.brief_description: Paul Newman stars as “Cool Hand Luke”, the irreverent loner, sentenced to work on a chain gang for destroying parking meters. George Kennedy stars as the sadistic convict boss who tries to break Newman’s spirit by using an arsenal of punishments and torture such as ‘the box’; a windowless cubicle designed to drive an inmate insane. In one of his most memorable parts, Newman as Luke, will not allow himself to succumb to the arbitrary rules of captivity. Nevertheless, the audience is left with an impression of Luke as a victim to be pitied rather than scorned.

results.title: Triumph of the spirit
results.creator_credit: Robert Young, Shimon Arama, Arnold Kopelson and Nova International
results.brief_description: The unimaginable horror of Auschwitz is compelling recreated in this overwhelming and powerful story about fighting for survival. Salamo Arouch (Willem Dafoe) is a Greek boxer who fought in the Olympics and is sent to the Auschwitz death camp. There he must battle every day against the inevitability of death with courage and an undaunted will to live being his only weapons. His struggle is a real “Triumph of the spirit.” Co-starring Edward James Olmos and Robert Loggia.

results.title: Here comes Mr. Jordan
results.creator_credit: Alexander Hall, Everett Riskin and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Joe Pendleton (Robert Montgomery), is a contender for the light heavyweight boxing crown, but is killed in a plane crash. An angel (Edward Everett Horton), realising the error that Joe has arrived in heaven 50 years too early. Trying to rectify the mistake, Mr. Jordon (Claude Rains), the chief deispatcher of the “Heavenly Express” sends Joe back to earth in the body of a just-murdered millionaire. This delightful romantic comedy was so successful, it inspired a musical sequel, “Down to Earth” and was remade as “Heaven can wait” in 1978.

results.title: Patton
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Frank McCarthy and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: General Patton was the only Allied General truly feared by the Nazi’s. In this riveting portrait of one of the greatest military minds of the modern world, George C. Scott gives an Award winning performance. Patton designed his own uniforms, sported ivory-handled six-shooters, and believed he was a warrior in past lives. Outwitting Rommel in Africa, after D-Day he led his troops across Europe. Rebellious and brilliant, he struggled with his own volatile personality. Co-starring Karl Malden, screenplay by Francis Ford Coppola and Edmund H. North and winner of eight Academy Awards in 1970.

results.title: Edward Scissorhands
results.creator_credit: Tim Burton, Denise Di Novi and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A lonely old inventor in a castle upon a hill dies and leaves his greatest creation, a boy called Edward, unfinished. Instead of hands, the boy has sharp shears of metal. Until his rescue by a kindly Avon lady who takes him home to the pastel paradise of suburbia, Edward lives alone in darkness. “Edward Scissorhands” is more than a fairy tale by masterful director Tim Burton. This is a satire/allegory which is both funny and moving. Johhny Depp as Edward is a gentle creature full of pathos, yet dignified; much less a monster than the fickle humans who at first embrace him and then seek to destroy him. Dianne Weist stars as Avon Lady Peg, and Winona Ryder as her daughter, Kim. The sets are typical of Burton’s famed surreal style. “Edward Scissorhands” is a film of great poignancy with its own special beauty.
